If a person attempts to redeem a previously pawned regulated firearm, the pawnbroker shall determine whether the person is the same individual who deposited the firearm with the pawnbroker as a pledge by requiring the person to display a driver’s license, an age of majority card, or other acceptable photographic identification.

If a person attempting to redeem a previously pawned regulated firearm is not the same individual who deposited the firearm with the pawnbroker, then the transfer of the regulated firearm shall comply with the provisions of this chapter and Public Safety Article, Title 5, Subtitle 1, Annotated Code of Maryland.

If the period allowed for redemption of a pawned regulated firearm has elapsed and the pawnbroker offers the regulated firearm for sale or rental, then the transfer of the regulated firearm shall comply with the provisions of this chapter and Public Safety Article, Title 5, Subtitle 1, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The pawnbroker shall notify the prospective transferee that the transferee is subject to the provisions of this chapter and Public Safety Article, Title 5, Subtitle 1, Annotated Code of Maryland.

The pawnbroker shall write on all pawn tickets issued for pawned regulated firearms: “This pawn ticket is transferable subject to the provisions of Public Safety Article, Title 5, Subtitle 1, Annotated Code of Maryland.”

section.heading: Public Auctions and Flea Markets.
section.text: The sale, rental, or transfer of a regulated firearm at a public auction or a flea market shall comply with the provisions of this chapter and Public Safety Article, Title 5, Subtitle 1, Annotated Code of Maryland.

para.text: A dealer may not sell, offer for sale, rent, or transfer a handgun manufactured on or before December 31, 2002, unless the handgun is sold, offered for sale, rented, or transferred with an external safety lock.

A dealer may not sell, offer for sale, rent, or transfer a handgun manufactured on or after January 1, 2003, unless the handgun is sold, offered for sale, rented, or transferred with an approved integrated mechanical safety device.
The provisions of this regulation do not apply to:
An antique firearm;
A firearm modified to render it permanently inoperative;
A sale or transfer by a dealer or manufacturer to a lawful customer outside the State; or
A purchase, sale, transfer, or transport to or by a dealer or manufacturer that provides or services a handgun for:
Personnel of the United States government or an agency or department of the United States government;
Members of the armed forces of the United States or the National Guard;
Law enforcement personnel of the State or any local law enforcement agency in the State while acting within the scope of their official duties; or
An organization that is required by federal law or regulations governing its specific business or activity to maintain handguns and applicable ammunition.
A licensed dealer may not conduct business and store firearms at a location unless:

The premises on which the licensed dealer operates is equipped with the security features specified in Public Safety Article, §5-145.1(a)(1), Annotated Code of Maryland, and §§B — D of this regulation; or
Outside business hours, the licensed dealer locks all firearms stored on premises in:
A vault;
A safe; or
A room or building that meets the requirements of Public Safety Article, §5-145.1(a)(1), Annotated Code of Maryland, and §§B — D of this regulation.
Video security equipment shall:
Record 24 hours a day, 365 days a year, without interruption;
Provide a date and time stamp for every recorded frame;
Record activity inside and outside the place of business to include:
Each entrance and exit of the place of business; and
Either:
Exterior parking areas leading up to and from the place of business; or
Exterior corridors leading up to and from the place of business if the parking area is not continuous to the business;
Have limited and secured access to the stored footage in a format that can be easily accessed for investigational purposes;
Retain recordings of security footage for a minimum of 90 days; and
Make footage available upon request by a law enforcement agency within 48 hours.
Burglary Alarm System Requirements. A security system shall be continually monitored and cover all perimeter entry and exit points.
Physical barriers may include:
Bollards, concrete barriers, steel barricades, planters, landscape boulders, terrain, building construction, and elevation or another physical barrier that prevents intrusion into the building; and
Security gates, screens, shutters, bars, security window film, or window grilles.
Inspection. The Secretary:
Shall inspect the security requirements of a licensed dealer at least once every 2 years; and

May inspect the security requirements at any time before being approved for a license, as a follow-up to a non-compliant inspection, during required inventory and record audits, and following a burglary/theft or attempts thereof.
Non-Compliance.
A person who violates this section is subject to a civil penalty not exceeding $1,000 imposed by the Secretary.
In addition to the penalty imposed under §F(1) of this regulation, a person who knowingly and willfully violates this section is subject to:
Suspension of the person’s dealer’s license upon a second offense, with the suspension remaining in effect until compliance is regained; and
Revocation of the person’s dealer’s license upon a third or subsequent offense.
